history.content: CS61C is extremely important for 162. Don't consider taking 162 without 61C. Drop Data 100 over summer and take CS61C. Taking 162 and Data 100 together next year is much more manageable since Data 100 is a very light class, even in its current iteration.

children.subject: If you don't mind sharing, why do you want to avoid 61C even though its a lower division requirement. Honestly, I'd recommend you to take take 61C this Fall not just to prepare you for 162 but also because Garcia is teaching it.

Hello, as I mentioned it, I’m a Data science major so I do not need CS 61c for a lower division requirement. And also since I am Junior transfer student, I only have two semesters more to finish my upper division requirements...

And the more popular professor, the harder to enroll in the class without registration priority. Also, only two more semesters to graduate. So I would take it asap rather than waiting for popular professor.
I'm pretty sure transfer students can take 5 semesters
Oh... my bad. Sorry for confusion. I meant I was a transfer student. I transferred Fall 2018.

If you don't want to take 61C, I don't think you should be taking 162 either. As a DS major, it might not be the most important class to take for you unless you're looking for SWE jobs.

Obv there's nothing stopping you from enrolling you in 162 since like you said, CS classes don't enforce prereqs, but it is quite likely that you'll have an extremely difficult semester without the background since 162 is considered to be a hellish class even for CS majors; also I'd pity your project group too..

There's absolutely no reason for you to take 162 if you don't want to take 61C. 162 isn't a crucial class at all. 61B is for SWE, and your DS classes will be for DS.

Forget about the fact your partners will spend a lot of time carrying you in many aspects due to lack of 61C and GDB experience.

If you think 162 is crucial to become a SWE(It's not), then you should certainly think the same for 61C because that's basically an introduction to many building blocks that will help you understand OS.

2 semesters left, that's great. If you are not interested in taking 61c, don't take 162. 186, 161, 168 are fantastic classes that don't need 61C and will give you great information that introduces you to this realm of SWE.

I'll argue many concepts in 162 are very important to be a great SWE, especially multithreading and synchronization. The class is also going to teach more practical distributed systems topics this Fall, which is becoming more of a necessity for SWEs to understand. That being, said, the 162 is quite hard without 61c, but I have seen (talented) people pull this off. At the very least you should be very comfortable with C programming and concepts like the virtual address space going on.

True, 162 is a great class for certain specializations and could be a useful class, but OP could self study it, after taking 61c, and certainly after exposure to other courses like 161, 168, 186(more or less). I know plenty of people who never took an OS class in school, some didn't even major in CS(just took lower divs and a few upper divs) and are great Software Engineers in industry the last 5-10 years.

Based on OP's interests, he/she should do 61C in fall and take 162 in spring, but if 162 can't fit in their schedule, they will be okay.

OP can always self study 162 in the future. Your career won't be destroyed because you didn't take an OS class.

For what it's worth, those 2 topics came up during one of my internships, and I did not know OS concepts. My mentor taught them to me in 1 hour.

Thank you for all your awesome opinions!

For those who thought I was not interested in taking CS 61C, that is not true. I wanted to take it but I could not due to my schedule and that was why I wondered how it is important to do well in CS 162. After I saw the student's answer, I learned that I needed to self-study it.

And the reason why I decided to take CS 162 was that I wanted to work before going for Master and there were plenty of opportunities for SWE than DS (because most of the employers want at least Master degree for that).

Thank you for the reply. After I saw your answer, I was working on modifying my academic plan. But since registration is already started and without registration priority (I’m Data science major), it is very hard to modify. Is it still possible to enroll in CS 162 without 61c prerequisite? I heard that we do not need to actually fulfill all the prerequisites in order to enroll in CS classes, but instead it’s like an advice to do well on the class. If so, I would like to self-study CS 61c during the summer and take CS 162 in the Fall with that knowledge. Or do I have a wrong information about prerequisites? Thank you.

history.content: Hello, I am planning on taking CS 162 in the next Fall semester but I did not take CS 61C yet. How is CS 61C important to do well in CS 162? If it is not super important and doable to succeed in CS 162 without 61C, I would not take 61C and just go for CS 162. Otherwise, I need to take it during the summer with Data 100. If so, how hard is the workload of CS 61C and Data 100 during the summer? Thank you.
history.subject: CS 61C for CS 162
